answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Alex,
As you may know, the new flood maps have created concerns over insurance premiums and property values for home owners.  The Town of Sturbridge, Massachusetts has provided their citizens with information on the revised FEMA flood maps, explaining the impact of the new Flood Hazard Maps and putting in place a 90-day “Public Comment Period” for residents who want to appeal the flood risk shown by the new maps. 
http://www.town.sturbridge.ma.us/Public_Documents/SturbridgeMA_Depts/S025709DA?Close=-1 
Insurance Matters, a document on the Knowledge Network is also useful as it provides an overview of FEMA insurance requirements and recommends steps municipalities can take to ensure protection. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/100018/Insurance_Matters 
Have any other communities taken steps to make citizens aware of the new maps?
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Alex Brown
text:
A recent Knowledge Network blog summarized the flood threat that accompanies rising water levels in the Mississippi River. Flood damage can be costly for governments, but so can the purchase of flood insurance before an event actually takes place.
FEMA is currently working to update the nation's flood maps. After implementing (and eventually abandoning) a controversial strategy that would treat existing non-accredited levees as "non-existent," governments are left to await whether policy changes will affect whether or not citizens will need to purchase costly flood insurance.
How do you expect the updated flood maps to impact citizens living in your community?
title: Flood Insurance Changes
